page.title: 03COASTAL EROSION
page.content: This area of coastland is very exposed and vulnerable to the strong waves and tides which are the main cause of erosion. The cliffs are composed of rocks of varying resistance to erosion and the waves exploit this characteristic by eroding the softer rocks at the base of the cliffs, leaving layers of more resistant rock unsupported. This rock eventually falls and the coastline retreats. Erosion has taken place here for hundreds of years so it is not a new problem. In some places in St. Andrews, the cliffs have been stabilised, but it is an expensive job and the cliffs to the East of St. Andrews cover such a large area that protection is not economically possible, so the cliffs remain open and exposed to the wind and waves.
